sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on Survival in Jamestown. The Struggles of the First Permanent English Colony (1607-1620). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Samuel, age 14, an indentured servant in Jamestown, 1609.

My name is Samuel, and I am fourteen years old. I came to Virginia as an indentured servant, bound to work for seven years in exchange for passage to this new land. The Virginia Company promised riches and opportunity, but what I found was something very different. When our ship sailed up the James River in the spring of 1609, I saw a small fort surrounded by endless forests.
sections.key_takeaway: My name is Samuel, and I am fourteen years old.

sections.narration: The winter of 1609 brought horror beyond imagination. We called it the "Starving Time." Captain Smith had been injured and returned to England, leaving us without strong leadership. The Powhatans, tired of our demands for food, stopped trading with us and surrounded the fort. We were trapped.
sections.key_takeaway: The winter of 1609 brought horror beyond imagination.

sections.narration: A man named John Rolfe changed everything when he began growing tobacco. He experimented with seeds from the Caribbean, creating a variety that grew well in Virginia's soil and tasted sweet when smoked. The English couldn't get enough of it. Suddenly, we had found our gold—not the metal kind, but green leaves that brought profit.
visuals: Chapter title: Tobacco Saves the Colony
sections.key_takeaway: A man named John Rolfe changed everything when he began growing tobacco.

sections.narration: In 1619, something remarkable happened. The Virginia Company allowed us to form the House of Burgesses, the first representative assembly in the American colonies. We could elect burgesses to make local laws, as long as they didn't contradict the company's rules or English law. For the first time, colonists had a voice in their own government.
visuals: Chapter title: The First Representative Government

sections.narration: Today I am twenty-four years old. Three years ago I completed my seven years of indenture and became a free man. Master Thompson gave me my freedom dues: fifty acres of land, tools, seed corn, and two sets of clothes. I own nothing else, but I own myself, and that means everything.
visuals: Chapter title: Freedom's Promise and Price
sections.key_takeaway: Today I am twenty-four years old.

sections.narration: In this lesson, we explored Survival in Jamestown through 5 chapters. Key concepts included: Jamestown, Virginia Company, John Smith, Starving Time.
